Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 06:20PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: I would get it removed.  I was diagnosed with a radial scar in 2001 and had is removed at that time.  A lumpectomy which was easy with no problems in recovery.  Then in Oct 2008 I found an indentation and a lump.  There were two tumors next to each other IDC and ILC, HER2 +++.  So be sure to keep a check on it very closely in the coming years.  Kathy

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2014 05:38PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: Ladies, thank you so very much for all your help.  I am going to be optomistic and go with no side effects but realistically I will get all.  When I was first diagnosed I had no problems with any treatments.  This time it seems if there is a side effect, I will get it.  Although, I did well with Taxol this time except for neuropathy after about 18 weekly treatments.  I have a bone scan Monday.  What fun as I still have that nasty burn on my back from the radiation.  It has been 4 months but it is slowly healing.  Again, thank you for all your help and support. Blessings, all

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2013 09:02AM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: dbla, I love your sense of humor.  I am one of those people that when stressed or upset I use inappropriate humor.  I told my 18 year old that if I crack a joke that seems inappropriate for the situation, don't be surprised.  She said but what if I don't think it is funny.  I said, you just better laugh.  It is good to smile and laugh in the midst of all this.  I have told friends that the thing that most makes me mad is, my husband just brought me back several boxes of hair color from the states and I had given away all my pretty scarves to the ladies at the hospital.  You just gotta laugh. Thank you and God Bless, Kathy

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 09:44PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: Well back to the doc on Thursday.  He said there is a slight possiblity that I have fibrosis but that is very rare.  I got three more breathing treatments and he put me on Allegra and Singulair and some new cough meds and still on the inhalers.  Then went back on Friday and he said I sounded much better.  Had a bad day Saturday, but better today.  Back to the doctor tomorrow.  Just when you think it is getting easier.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2013 12:17PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: Thank you ladies for answering for of my questions before I asked them, such as pain from the Zometa.  Does this improve as time goes on?  It has been a tough week, but feeling better today.  My husband and daughter are busy getting us packed and moved.  I have been in bed since Monday.  I may never find everything again but at least it is all getting moved to our new place.  I just have to remember calm when I try to unpack next week.  lol  I pray everyone will have a good weekend, all treatments will kick in for everyone and knock this cancer back!!  Blessings, Kathy
Posts.Title: (I Kinda Knew It, But) CRAP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! dbla dbla

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 07:06PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: The last week of radiation I too had shortness of breath and then developed a cough and 103 fever.  After three days my husband insisted I go to the ER and sure enough they said pneumonia.  They gave me a breathing treatment, antibiotics, Tylenol, and cough syrup.  Then a week later I had an appointment with oncologist and she said it sounded like asthma and put me on steroids and two inhalers.  It has been a week and the cough is no better so I am back to the clinic tomorrow.  We are headed to the U.S. in one week and I don't want anything to mess that up.  Kathy

Posts.Title: Prayers for TerryO's Cathy dreamwriter carol1949

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 05:52PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: If I remember correctly, the only time my breast was touched was during the markings.  I always had male techs and they were young men.  They were always very professional and a gown covered the non radiated breast.  They always called me by name and even with the language barrier it went very well.  They knew some english and along with my limited spanish the time sped by.  I actually felt sorry for them having to look at my old lady scarred up breast, but you could tell they were there to help get rid of those cancer cells.  The whole procedure took 5 minutes max, except for the initial measuring sessions.  I would bring goodies once a week for the staff and patients and the time went very fast.  The nearly seven weeks went by very fast.  I will pray for you that your time goes by quickly and they make it as comfortable as possible for you.  God Bless, Kathy

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 02:25PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: Hairspraymom, I would love to have the pattern.  I am a missionary here in Costa Rica and have been undergoing treatment for BC here for the last year.  I started making scarves for the other ladies and now bring donations back from the U.S. of bras, prosthesis, scarves, etc and we have expanded our ministry to help the government hospital where I am receiving treatment.  I would love to be able to make these aprons if you could send me the pattern.  If this is possible let me know and I can send you an address in the U.S. to send it to as we have a mission group coming down in the spring.  Thank you and God Bless, Kathy
Posts.Title: Do you need a mastec/recon apron? HairSprayMom HairSprayMom

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2009 11:50PM MRSROCKYTOP55 wrote: Kate, I am a  missionary here in Costa Rica and have been receiving treatment for BC since last November.  Currently I am having radiation and Herceptin.  While receiving chemo at the government hospital I noticed many ladies who did not even have scarves, wigs, etc.  I spoke with the head nurse and she said they also had a great need for prosthesis and bras.  I have brought some back with me from the U.S. and also a mission group brought a box.  When I brought these to the hospital, they were so excited.  I have met several of the women who have received prosthesis and their were many tears between us.  I am going to the states to visit family in November and if you would like to donate your prosthesis just send me a PM and I will send you an address in the U.S.  God Bless, Kathy
